im wondering what happend if you rewrite a given function as "(a) times 1" where "a" is the function and you express that "1" as a "x-b/x-b" where b is a real number. That will create a void spot in the domain out of thin air! Can you please point out the mistake in my reasoning?

Aren't you essentially multiplying two functions here? x-b/x-b could be defined as another function and multiplying two functions can change the set of domain values, as far as I understand.
Thank you for answer! but that function is equal to 1 so it does not change the function that is multiply by it.
@aveinmovil  Yes, but the domain of this new function x-b/x-b is all real number values except 'b'. So the domain has changed. Now, when you multiply them together, you get a new domain.
Yep, local and relative are interchangeable.

Yes. 03:14. It's a strange one and I'm still trying to figure out what he meant. Even if he meant f(x) = 3 then the domain is still all real numbers and it would be the RANGE that is limited to just 3.
